Posts.Content: Apr 14, 2009 05:55PM QueenSansaStark wrote: Since you are over 40 and ER+, if you don't go into menopause after treatment you should deeply consider having that ooph. You do NOT want any estrogens hanging around for tumor food! I was 43 at dx and my BC was 100% ER/PR. I went into menopause after chemo and my onc said that was the best thing that could ever happen to me because I was so highly hormone-positive. I am two years out and on Tamoxifen (no AI for me because I have a very high risk of osteoporosis). The side effects stink, but taking vitamins for energy, and Tazo Calm tea and melatonin to sleep helps a lot.  If I hadn't gone into menopause I would have had Lupron shots or the ooph, just because of being so highly hormone-positive. http://www.hystersisters.com is a great website for women considering an ooph or who have had one.
Posts.Title: Ovaries and all that stuff..... thisisme nobleanna007

Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2009 05:15PM QueenSansaStark wrote: Lori, I want to tell you about my mom, another BC survivor. When dx'd, she had a HUGE (like tangerine sized) tumor, tons of nodes, AND a (thankfully) isolated lung met and now she's a seven-year NED (that is seven years, NO evidence of disease ANYWHERE) because she was also ER/PR 100% and took Arimidex for five years. Arimidex and Femara are powerful for us highly hormone + gals. I'm going to take Femara, bones or no bones, when my course of Tamoxifen is done. I had the blood tests done and apparently the chemo put me in permanent menopause - I haven't had a period for two years. I like to think the cancer is starved to death.

Posts.Content: May 4, 2008 05:25PM QueenSansaStark wrote: I know to hear "Stage III" is scary but lots of women have long healthy happy lives after a Stage III diagnosis. There is a lot more to throw at BC than there once was. If you are ER/PR+ there is Tamoxifen and the AI's. If you are HER2+ there is Herceptin and Tykerb. If you are triple negative - triple negs are the ones who get most benefit from chemo, and the taxanes are really improving outcomes for ladies who get chemo. I myself used conventional (chemo, rads, Tamoxifen) and alternative (acupuncture, vitamins, spiritual healing) methods. I know it's hard when you are first diagnosed and are sitting there gobsmacked and scared to death, but keep a positive attitude and know that the odds ARE on your side.
Posts.Title: Prognosis? dcjoslin56 florencedonna

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2008 01:16AM QueenSansaStark wrote: IBCSpouse, thank you for posting the article. Very interesting! All the more reason for us ER/PR+ gals to keep taking those AIs or tamoxifen! I wonder if the reason for the higher ER/PR+ recurrence rates is that tamox and AIs are only given for five years? Maybe we need to take them longer. As far as Stage III is concerned, I believe that women who might have been considered Stage IIb in the past are now sometimes being reclassified as Stage III. That is, it's no longer considered necessary to have fixed or matted nodes or a huge tumor - just over a certain size and/or number of nodes and you are in the Stage III area.  This has to make a difference in survival rates (as well as scaring the beejabbers out of a lot of women who are reclassified as Stage III). AI's, Herceptin,  Tykerb, and the taxane chemos were not available a few years ago and now they are making a huge difference in survival. New therapies are being discovered all the time.
Posts.Title: onc says my stage III no big deal scorpio QueenSansaStark

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2008 04:18PM QueenSansaStark wrote: I never was told to "not use mass transit". BUT - I was on A/C/Taxotere and that really did a number on my immune system (I had neutropenia). I took Neupogen shots but still had to take precautions. I don't think it's necessary to drive or stay home all month. But during the time your WBC is low, drive or work from home is probably the best option.
Posts.Title: Chemo and mass transportation NancyD QueenSansaStark

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2008 05:09PM QueenSansaStark wrote: There are a couple of things that can contribute to fatigue in menopausal (or chemopausal) women: - Thyroid problems: these are VERY VERY common in women, and chemo has been known to do a number on the thyroid as well (it makes sense, if it can shut down our ovaries, it can shut down our thyroid). Have your doc test you for hypothyroidism. If you are hypothyroid, you can get Synthroid which will make a huge difference in your energy level. - Sleep apnea. Progesterone and estrogen protect us before menopause, but afterwards, we are vulnerable, especially those of us who are ER/PR+ and on Tamoxifen or AIs. Do you snore loud enough to warrant comparisons to a freight train or grizzly bear? Does your bed partner tell you that you stop breathing and gasp/snort for breath during the night? Sleep apnea keeps you from getting refreshing sleep at night and you feel sleep-deprived and fatigued during the day. Ask for a sleep test.
Posts.Title: Still have the fatigue after 2 years. Mary-Lou Molly2013

Posts.Content: Sep 19, 2008 10:19AM QueenSansaStark wrote: Harley, the Tamox gives me gawdawful hot flashes too - while it means it's working, it is HELL on my sleeping patterns. This doesn't help my energy level. I think a lot of us ER+ gals on Tamox or one of the AIs get disrupted sleep because of the lack of estrogen. Valerian root (which smells just like toe jam) and a hot bath help me to relax and get to sleep. Also, I'm on Synthroid for my thyroid and it's worked a miracle. Not just on my energy level but on my cholesterol, insulin resistance and weight gain - I lost 10 lbs just from getting my thyroid hormones back! I really think all BC survivors, especially those who have undergone chemo, need a thyroid check.
Posts.Title: Still have the fatigue after 2 years. Mary-Lou Molly2013

Posts.Content: Jul 8, 2007 03:24PM QueenSansaStark wrote: Have her onc check her red blood cell count. I became severely anemic on TAC and getting an iron infusion helped me a LOT. Anemia can cause fatigue and shortness of breath.
Posts.Title: Extreme Fatigue? shopper16 shopper16

Posts.Content: Mar 18, 2008 09:37PM QueenSansaStark wrote: I gained A LOT of weight during and post-chemo and Tamoxifen, alas. The major problem I had that started the whole thing snowballing, was neutropenia (bad enough that I was hospitalized once) during chemo. I had the best intentions to eat a healthy raw diet but, alas! Everything I ate had to be cooked or at least peeled! So I ate more bad food than I should have, and it became a habit. Now I'm starting a diet and exercise program. Not only do I want to fit into my pants again, weight gain is bad for us ER+ types as fat either produces or stores estrogen (I forget).

Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2007 12:00PM QueenSansaStark wrote: I am on TAC (Taxotere/Adria/Cytoxan) and got a Neulasta shot after my first tx. Well, apparently my body said, "I bite my thumb at thee, Neulasta!" because I wound up in the hospital with a neutropenic fever and systemic infection. My onc switched me over to Neupogen, which is given every day, and so far, so good. You might want to try Neupogen instead. Sorry you had to cancel your trip, what a bummer!

Posts.Content: Jun 8, 2014 09:04PM - edited Jun 8, 2014 09:04PM by QueenSansaStark Dear AlienWish, I was diagnosed at 43, just a year older than you. I celebrated my seven years' survival in February. My latest mammo is clean. I have nice long hair and a good life. When I was diagnosed I was just beside myself - the "C" word is scary! But here I am, and I hope to live a long life to come. BC treatment has come a long way even since I was diagnosed, and progress is made every year. Many women who have small, early-stage, hormone positive cancers don't even have to have chemo, as the hormone blockers are so effective.  There's lots and lots of great information and terrific women (and men) here on these boards.

Posts.Content: May 11, 2008 10:58AM QueenSansaStark wrote: Is there hope for your sister? OH YES! Many, many Stage III girls are alive and well years after diagnosis. Even women with Stage IV can live productively for many years. Statistics are outdated. Throw them out and disregard them. There is so much more that can be done for BC now than there was even five years ago. So give your sister all the positive, encouraging news you can and tell her to keep her hopes up!

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2009 01:02PM QueenSansaStark wrote: I believe that cancer isn't just one disease, but a constellation of different ones. My ER/PR+++ BC isn't the same BC as, say, my friend S's triple positive (ER/PR/HER2) BC.  That said, maybe I'm foolishly optimistic, but I believe there will be a cure for at least a few types of cancer in my lifetime. My great-great grandma died of pneumonia, which was turned from "fatal" to "mostly curable" thanks to antibiotics. Just last year people were saying NO WAY could a black man with a "foreign sounding" name be elected US President. Well, now we have our President Obama! So I have my faith in a cure for at least some types of C. I think we will also be discovering more chemicals and things in our daily lives that cause cancer and these will be eliminated. I'm old enough to remember leaded gasoline and now everything is unleaded. My mom and I are both survivors of ER/PR+++ BC and I firmly believe that there was/is some kind of environmental cause - chemicals in plastic maybe? And I will go right now to the Alaska Deb thread and join in. I didn't know her well but I remember her posts on this board and how fun and funny she was.
